case_name: Mst. Rafiquennessa v. Lal Bahadur Chetri

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 549 of 1962 is an appeal from the judgment and orders dated August 1, 1958 and March 13, 1959 of the Assam High Court in A. Nos. 86 of 1958 and 14 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION CIVIL Appeal No. 549 of 1962. Appeals from the judgment and orders dated August 1, 1958 and March 13, 1959 of the Assam High Court A. Nos. 86 of 1958 and 14 of 1959 respectively. C. Chatterjee, K. P. Sen and P. K. Chatterjee, for the appellant  in C.A. No. 549 of 1962 .

facts.text: Lal Bahadur Chetri executed a registered lease-deed in favour of the appellant Mst. Rafiquennessa on the 14th February, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Lal Bahadur Chetri has executed a registered lease-deed in favour of the appellant on the 14th February, 1946. The lease companyered an open plot of land and under the companyenant the leasee was entitled to build a house for residential purposes.

facts.text: The lease covered an open plot of land and the lessee was entitled to build a house for residential purposes.

anchor.surface_text: The lease companyered an open plot of land and under the companyenant the leasee was entitled to build a house for residential purposes. In the ordinary companyrse, the lease was due to expire on the 12th February, 1952, and the lessee had agreed to deliver vacant possession of the land at the expiration of the stipulated period.

facts.text: The lease was due to expire on the 12th February, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: In the ordinary companyrse, the lease was due to expire on the 12th February, 1952, and the lessee had agreed to deliver vacant possession of the land at the expiration of the stipulated period. Accordingly, a numberice to quit was served on him to vacate on the 12th February, 1952.

facts.text: A notice to quit was served on the lessee to vacate on the 12th February, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, a numberice to quit was served on him to vacate on the 12th February, 1952. He, however, did number companyply with the numberice and that led to the present suit by the appellant for eviction  No. 149 of 1952 .

facts.text: The appellant filed suit No. 149 of 1952 for eviction against the lessee.

anchor.surface_text: He, however, did number companyply with the numberice and that led to the present suit by the appellant for eviction  No. 149 of 1952 . In support of her claim, the appellant alleged that the lessee had companytravened the terms of the lease inasmuch as he had sublet the premises built by him, and so, that was an additional ground for evicting the lessee.

facts.text: The appellant alleged that the lessee had sublet the premises.

anchor.surface_text: In support of her claim, the appellant alleged that the lessee had companytravened the terms of the lease inasmuch as he had sublet the premises built by him, and so, that was an additional ground for evicting the lessee. The sub-lessees were accordingly joined as defendants to the suit.

facts.text: The trial Judge decreed the appellant's claim.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge decreed the appellants claim where- upon the lessee Chetri filed an appeal in the Court of the Sub-Judge, Lower Assam District, Gauhati, challenging the validity and the companyrectness of the decree passed against him  Civil Appeal No. 24/1953 .

facts.text: Lessee Chetri filed Civil Appeal No. 24/1953 in the Court of the Sub-Judge, Lower Assam District, Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: where- upon the lessee Chetri filed an appeal in the Court of the Sub-Judge, Lower Assam District, Gauhati, challenging the validity and the companyrectness of the decree passed against him  Civil Appeal No. 24/1953 . While the appeal was pending, the Act was passed and was published in the Assam Gazette on the 6th July, 1955.

facts.text: The Assam Non-Agricultural Urban Area Tenancy Act, 1955 (No. 12 of 1955) was published in the Assam Gazette on the 6th July, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: While the appeal was pending, the Act was passed and was published in the Assam Gazette on the 6th July, 1955. Thereafter, when the appeal came on for hearing before the lower appellate Court, the tenant filed an application praying that he should be permitted to take an additional ground under s. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: The lower appellate Court allowed the tenant's plea under s.5, framed an additional issue, and remanded the matter to the trial Court.

anchor.surface_text: Before that date, the Assam High Court had taken the view that the said provision of the Act was applicable to the pending proceedings between land- lords and tenants for eviction and that was the basis on which the tenant Chetri wanted to support his appeal. The lower appellate Court allowed the tenants plea, framed an additional issue in pursuance of it and sent the matter back to the trial Court for a finding.

facts.text: On remand, the trial Court found that the two houses built by the tenant were permanent in relation to the locality but there was no evidence when constructed.

anchor.surface_text: On remand, the trial Court took evidence and after local inspection, made a finding that the two houses proved to have been built by the tenant must be regarded as permanent in relation to the locality of the plot. He, however, found that there was numberevidence to show when the said houses were companystructed.

facts.text: The lower appellate Court found that the two houses were constructed within five years after the taking of the lease.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion of the lower appellate Court was that the two houses had been companystructed by the tenant within five years after the taking of the lease and that entitled the lessee to claim the benefit of s. 5 of the Act.

facts.text: The lower appellate Court allowed the appeal and set aside the decree of the trial Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The lower appel- late Court ultimately allowed the appeal and set aside the decree passed by the trial Judge in favour of the appellant.

facts.text: The appellant filed second appeal No. 86/1958 in the Assam High Court, which was summarily dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then preferred a second appeal in the High Court of Assam  No. 86/1958 . Following its earlier decision about the applicability of the provisions of s. 5 to pending proceedings, the High Court summarily dismissed the said appeal.

facts.text: Assam High Court issued certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant applied for and obtained a certificate from the High Court and with the said certificate the present appeal has been brought before us.

facts.text: Pending proceedings, tenant Chetri died and his heirs Mst. Tulsa Devi and others were brought on record as respondents.

anchor.surface_text: Pending these proceedings, the tenant Chetri died and his heirs and legal representatives Mst. Tulsa Devi and others. have been brought on the record and will be described as respondents hereafter.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 569 of 1963 arises from a suit by appellant Wahedulla against tenant respondent Abdul Hamid with similar facts.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 569 of 1963 arises from a suit filed by the appellant Wahedulla against his tenant, the respondent Abdul Hamid. The relevant facts are similar to those in C.A. No. 549/1962.

facts.text: The Act was passed by the Assam Legislature to regulate relationship between landlord and tenant in respect of non-agricultural lands in urban areas.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed by the Assam Legislature in order to regulate in certain respects the relationship between land- lord and tenant in respect of number-agricultural lands in the urban areas of the State of Assam.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered on February 24, 1964 by GAJENDRAGADKAR C.J.

anchor.surface_text: February 24, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR C.J.-These two appeals which have been brought to this Court with a certificate issued by the Assam High Court, raise a short question about the companystruction and effect of section 5 of the Assam NonAgricultural Urban Area Tenancy Act, 1955  No. 12 of 1955   hereinafter called the Act .

facts.text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

raise a short question about the construction and effect of section 5 of the Assam NonAgricultural Urban Area Tenancy Act, 1955 (No. 12 of 1955) hereinafter called the Act . The relevant and material facts which have led to the suits from which these two appeals respectively arise, are similar,

concepts.interpretation: Provisions apply retrospectively to pending eviction proceedings; protects tenants who built permanent structures within 5 years of lease contract, even if built before the Act; prohibits eviction except for non-payment of rent.

concepts.unlisted_description: Regulates ejectment of tenants who have built permanent structures or made improvements.

anchor.surface_text: Before doing so, it is necessary to consider s. 2 which provides that notwithstanding anything contained in any contract or in any law for the time being in force, the provisions of this Act shall apply to all non-agricultural tenancies whether created before or after the date on which this Act comes into force.

concepts.interpretation: Indicates legislative intent for the Act's provisions to apply to tenancies created before or after the Act's commencement, affecting prior vested rights.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee contends that the Assam High Court was in error in coming to the conclusion that the proceedings which were pending between the parties at the appellate stage on 6th July, 1955 when the Act came into force, fell to be governed by the provisions of s. 5. He argues that at the relevant date when the suit was filed by the appellant, he had acquired a right to eject the tenant under the terms of the tenancy, and he contends that where vested rights are affected by any statutory provision, the said provision should normally be construed to be prospective in operation and not retrospective, unless the provision in question relates merely to a procedural matter.

concepts.interpretation: A statutory provision is retroactive if expressly declared or if intent clearly implicit from words and context; applies even to vested rights if legislature intends; exception for purely procedural matters.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: esced in it. Thus, the plain object of s. 5 is to protect the tenants who have built a permanent structure either for business or for residence, provi

concepts.unlisted_description: General rule against retrospective effect on vested rights unless express or implicit legislative intent.

anchor.surface_text: Incidentally, an appeal pending before the lower appellate court is a continuation of the suit, and so, there is no difficulty in holding that a suit which was pending when the Act came into force would be governed by s. 5 (1) (a) and an appeal arising from a suit which had been decided before the Act came into force, would likewise be governed by s. 5 (1) (a), provided it is pending after the date when the Act came into force.

concepts.interpretation: Pending appeals are continuation of original suit, hence governed by new law if pending when new law comes into force.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 (c) defines a landlord as meaning a person immediately under whom a tenant holds but does not include the Government. While s. 3 (d) defines a Permanent structure in relation to any locality as meaning a structure which is regarded as permanent in that locality, the tenant and urban area are defined by clauses (g) and (b) respectively.

anchor.surface_text: s. 11 provides for notice for ejectment s. 12 prescribes the procedure in which the notice has to be served and s. 13 confers rule-making power on the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was passed by the Assam Legislature in order to regulate in certain respects the relationship between landlord and tenant in respect of non-agricultural lands in the urban areas of the State of Assam. It contains fourteen sections and the scheme which is evident in the operative provisions of the Act is to afford protection to the tenants by regulating in certain respects the relationship between them and their landlords in respect of the lands covered by the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Scheme of the Act is protective of tenants; provisions read to effectuate beneficent purpose.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: e scheme of the Act, it is necessary to read s. 5, the effect of which is the main point of companytroversy between the parties before us. Section 5 i

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section ( 2 ) prohibits the ejectment of any tenant from the land of the tenancy except in execution of a decree for ejectment passed by a competent civil Court

concepts.unlisted_description: Ejectment only executable on decree from competent court.

anchor.surface_text: These principles are unexceptionable and as a matter of law, no objection can be taken to them. Mr. Chatterjee has relied upon the well known observations made by Wright J. in in re Athlumney Ex parte Wilson [1] , when the learned Judge said that it is a general rule

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms general rules of construction cited by counsel, but finds implicit retrospectivity here.

precedents.citation: in re Athlumney Ex parte Wilson 1 1898 2 Q. B. D. 547

anchor.surface_text: in re Athlumney Ex parte Wilson 1 , when the learned Judge said that it is a general rule that when the Legislature alters the rights of parties by taking away or conferring any right of action, its enactments, unless in express terms they apply to pending actions, do not affect them. He added that there was one exception to that rule, namely, that, where enactments merely affect procedure and do not extend to rights of action, they have been held to apply to existing rights. In order to make the statement of the law relating to the relevant rule of construction which has to be adopted in dealing with the effect of statutory provisions in this connection, we ought to add that retroactive operation of a statutory provision can be inferred even in cases where such retroactive operation appears to be clearly implicit in the 1 1898 2 Q. B. D. 547.

Precedent p1's general rule on non-retrospectivity supports holding h6, which accepts these principles as unexceptionable while noting exceptions for inferred retroactivity
